comment_text.mn76:2.1: Neither Sandaka nor this location appear to be known elsewhere.
comment_text.mn76:3.2: Evidently an excursion for sightseeing was popular. As well as simply enjoying nature, such trips give the mendicants a chance to check out possible places to stay for meditation.
comment_text.mn76:4.7: This sentence is redundant as it stands. But wherever this idiom occurs elsewhere, it specifies that the person is a lay disciple (DN 25:3.5, MN 78:3.7, AN 10.93:2.7, AN 10.94:3.4). Perhaps the text here has been corrupted and originally specified that Ānanda was a monastic disciple.
comment_text.mn76:7.2: Attributed to Ajita of the hair blanket at DN 2:23.2. | The denial of “mother and father” is usually interpreted as the denial of moral duty towards one’s parents. However, I think it is a doctrine of conception which denies that a child is created by the mother and father. Rather, the child is produced by the four elements, with parents as mere instigators and incubators.
comment_text.mn76:7.3: This is a materialist analysis of the person. | The word kāya (“substance”) is central to Jainism. Ācārāṅgasūtra 8.1.11 speaks of the “substances” of earth, water, fire, and air as being imbued with life so one should avoid damaging them.
comment_text.mn76:10.2: Attributed to Pūraṇa Kassapa at DN 2:17.2. | This is a denial of the doctrine of kamma. While his doctrine appears to be morally nihilistic, it seems unlikely this was Pūraṇa Kassapa’s full teaching. He may have subscribed to hard determinism, so that we have no choice in what we do. He may also have believed that we should keep moral rules as a social contract, but that this had no effect on the afterlife. | In such contexts, kar- means “punish, inflict” (MN 129:29.2).
comment_text.mn76:13.2: This is the first part of the view attributed to the Bamboo-staffed Ascetic Gosāla at DN 2:20.2 and to Pūraṇa Kassapa at SN 22.60:2.2. | This denies the principle of causality and the efficacy of action. The fatalistic teachings of the Ājīvikas led to them becoming popular as prognosticators.
comment_text.mn76:13.6: The otherwise parallel passage has a different phrasing at DN 2:20.5.
comment_text.mn76:16.2: This combines the view attributed to Pakudha Kaccāyana (DN 2:26.2) with the second part of Gosāla’s view (DN 2:20.7). There are several inconsistencies in the presentation of these views in Pali, and still more when parallels are considered. These were closely-related teachers, who often practiced together for a time, and it is hardly surprising that they should share some views in common, or that their exact views have become confused.
comment_text.mn76:16.11: For explanations, see my note at DN 2:20.7.
comment_text.mn76:20.3: This section deals with religious claims to truth, which sound confident but turn out to be unreliable. Anassāsika (“unreliable”) normally describes “conditions”, where it is a synonym of anicca and adhuva (AN 7.66:2.3, DN 17:2.16.4, SN 15.20:2.12, SN 22.96:4.14). For its opposite assāsa as “certainty” see MN 11:3.2 and MN 93:6.7.
comment_text.mn76:21.4: Not only did the Buddha deny this kind of strong omniscience, he took pains to point out its absurdity.
comment_text.mn76:30.2: Vikkhepa is “ﬂip-flopping”. | Amarā is explained in the commentary as either “undying” or “eel-like”. However, amarā in the sense of “eel” is found only in the commentary to this term so is probably spurious.
comment_text.mn76:43.1: Bhikkhu here seems improbable, yet it is attested in the manuscripts.
comment_text.mn76:53.1: “(Those who are) emancipated” is niyyātāro, a unique occurrence of an agent noun from niyyāti, “to go out”. This was probably a technical term in Sandaka’s system.
comment_text.mn76:53.5: The commentary takes mata as “dead” and the compound puttamatāya as genitive feminine, yielding the sense, “she whose sons are dead”, explaining that Sandaka thought, “Those Ājīvakas are surely dead; their mother is she whose sons are dead”. Perhaps, however, “she whose sons are dead” is an allusion to a child-killing yakkhinī such as Hārītī of Madhurā or Kālī in the commentary to Dhp 5, thus having the force, “sons of a she-devil”. Either way this is a curse or slur intruding into a passage whose intent is to highlight the Buddha’s fair-minded treatment of others. A near-identical phrase is used of brutal bandits at Ja 79:1.3. The compound is inverted at SN 5.3:2.1, but seems to have the same meaning.

root_text.mn76:17.3: sattime kāyā akaṭā akaṭavidhā animmitā animmātā vañjhā kūṭaṭṭhā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā.
root_text.mn76:17.4: Te na iñjanti na vipariṇamanti na aññamaññaṁ byābādhenti.
root_text.mn76:17.5: Nālaṁ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā.
root_text.mn76:17.7: Pathavīkāyo āpokāyo tejokāyo vāyokāyo sukhe dukkhe jīve sattame—
root_text.mn76:17.8: ime satta kāyā akaṭā akaṭavidhā animmitā animmātā vañjhā kūṭaṭṭhā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā.
root_text.mn76:17.9: Te na iñjanti na vipariṇamanti na aññamaññaṁ byābādhenti.
root_text.mn76:17.10: Nālaṁ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā.
root_text.mn76:17.11: Tattha natthi hantā vā ghātetā vā sotā vā sāvetā vā viññātā vā viññāpetā vā.
root_text.mn76:17.12: Yopi tiṇhena satthena sīsaṁ chindati, na koci kañci jīvitā voropeti.
root_text.mn76:17.14: Cuddasa kho panimāni yonipamukhasatasahassāni saṭṭhi ca satāni cha ca satāni pañca ca kammuno satāni pañca ca kammāni tīṇi ca kammāni, kamme ca aḍḍhakamme ca, dvaṭṭhipaṭipadā, dvaṭṭhantarakappā, chaḷābhijātiyo, aṭṭha purisabhūmiyo, ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasate, ekūnapaññāsa paribbājakasate, ekūnapaññāsa nāgāvāsasate, vīse indriyasate, tiṁse nirayasate, chattiṁsa rajodhātuyo, satta saññīgabbhā, satta asaññīgabbhā, satta nigaṇṭhigabbhā, satta devā, satta mānusā, satta pesācā, satta sarā, satta pavuṭā, satta papātā, satta papātasatāni, satta supinā, satta supinasatāni, cullāsīti mahākappino satasahassāni, yāni bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṁsaritvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti.
root_text.mn76:17.15: Tattha natthi imināhaṁ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā aparipakkaṁ vā kammaṁ paripācessāmi, paripakkaṁ vā kammaṁ phussa phussa byantiṁ karissāmīti, hevaṁ natthi doṇamite sukhadukkhe pariyantakate saṁsāre, natthi hāyanavaḍḍhane, natthi ukkaṁsāvakaṁse.
root_text.mn76:17.16: Seyyathāpi nāma suttaguḷe khitte nibbeṭhiyamānameva paleti;
root_text.mn76:17.17: evameva bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṁsaritvā dukkhassantaṁ karissantī’ti.
root_text.mn76:17.18: Sace pana imassa bhoto satthuno saccaṁ vacanaṁ, akatena me ettha kataṁ, avusitena me ettha vusitaṁ.
root_text.mn76:17.19: Ubhopi mayaṁ ettha samasamā sāmaññaṁ pattā, yo cāhaṁ na vadāmi ‘ubho sandhāvitvā saṁsaritvā dukkhassantaṁ karissāmā’ti.
root_text.mn76:17.20: Atirekaṁ kho panimassa bhoto satthuno naggiyaṁ muṇḍiyaṁ ukkuṭikappadhānaṁ kesamassulocanaṁ, yohaṁ puttasambādhasayanaṁ ajjhāvasanto kāsikacandanaṁ paccanubhonto mālāgandhavilepanaṁ dhārento jātarūparajataṁ sādiyanto iminā bhotā satthārā samasamagatiko bhavissāmi abhisamparāyaṁ.
root_text.mn76:17.21: Sohaṁ kiṁ jānanto kiṁ passanto imasmiṁ satthari brahmacariyaṁ carissāmi?
root_text.mn76:17.23: iti viditvā tasmā brahmacariyā nibbijja pakkamati.
root_text.mn76:18.1: Ayaṁ kho, sandaka, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena catuttho abrahmacariyavāso akkhāto yattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ na vaseyya, vasanto ca nārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalaṁ.
root_text.mn76:19.1: Ime kho te, sandaka, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāro abrahmacariyavāsā akkhātā yattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ na vaseyya, vasanto ca nārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalan”ti.
root_text.mn76:20.2: Yāvañcidaṁ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāro abrahmacariyavāsāva samānā ‘abrahmacariyavāsā’ti akkhātā yattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ na vaseyya, vasanto ca nārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalanti.
root_text.mn76:20.3: Katamāni pana tāni, bho ānanda, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāri anassāsikāni brahmacariyāni akkhātāni yattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ na vaseyya, vasanto ca nārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalan”ti?
root_text.mn76:21.1: “Idha, sandaka, ekacco satthā sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paṭijānāti:
root_text.mn76:21.2: ‘carato ca me tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṁ samitaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paccupaṭṭhitan’ti.
root_text.mn76:21.3: So suññampi agāraṁ pavisati, piṇḍampi na labhati, kukkuropi ḍaṁsati, caṇḍenapi hatthinā samāgacchati, caṇḍenapi assena samāgacchati, caṇḍenapi goṇena samāgacchati, itthiyāpi purisassapi nāmampi gottampi pucchati, gāmassapi nigamassapi nāmampi maggampi pucchati.
root_text.mn76:21.4: So ‘kimidan’ti puṭṭho samāno ‘suññaṁ me agāraṁ pavisitabbaṁ ahosi’, tena pāvisiṁ; ‘piṇḍampi aladdhabbaṁ ahosi’, tena nālatthaṁ; ‘kukkurena ḍaṁsitabbaṁ ahosi’, tenamhi daṭṭho; ‘caṇḍena hatthinā samāgantabbaṁ ahosi’, tena samāgamiṁ; ‘caṇḍena assena samāgantabbaṁ ahosi’, tena samāgamiṁ; ‘caṇḍena goṇena samāgantabbaṁ ahosi’, tena samāgamiṁ; ‘itthiyāpi purisassapi nāmampi gottampi pucchitabbaṁ ahosi’, tena pucchiṁ; ‘gāmassapi nigamassapi nāmampi maggampi pucchitabbaṁ ahosi’, tena pucchinti.
root_text.mn76:22.1: Tatra, sandaka, viññū puriso iti paṭisañcikkhati:
root_text.mn76:22.2: ‘ayaṁ kho bhavaṁ satthā sabbaññū sabbadassāvī aparisesaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paṭijānāti …pe… ‘gāmassapi nigamassapi nāmampi maggampi pucchitabbaṁ ahosi, tena pucchin’ti.
root_text.mn76:22.4: iti viditvā tasmā brahmacariyā nibbijja pakkamati.
root_text.mn76:23.1: Idaṁ kho, sandaka, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena paṭhamaṁ anassāsikaṁ brahmacariyaṁ akkhātaṁ yattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ na vaseyya, vasanto ca nārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalaṁ.
root_text.mn76:24.1: Puna caparaṁ, sandaka, idhekacco satthā anussaviko hoti anussavasacco.
root_text.mn76:24.2: So anussavena itihitihaparamparāya piṭakasampadāya dhammaṁ deseti.
root_text.mn76:24.3: Anussavikassa kho pana, sandaka, satthuno anussavasaccassa sussutampi hoti dussutampi hoti tathāpi hoti aññathāpi hoti.
root_text.mn76:25.1: Tatra, sandaka, viññū puriso iti paṭisañcikkhati:
root_text.mn76:25.2: ‘ayaṁ kho bhavaṁ satthā anussaviko anussavasacco so anussavena itihitihaparamparāya piṭakasampadāya dhammaṁ deseti.
root_text.mn76:25.3: Anussavikassa kho pana satthuno anussavasaccassa sussutampi hoti dussutampi hoti tathāpi hoti aññathāpi hoti’.
root_text.mn76:25.5: iti viditvā tasmā brahmacariyā nibbijja pakkamati.
root_text.mn76:26.1: Idaṁ kho, sandaka, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena dutiyaṁ anassāsikaṁ brahmacariyaṁ akkhātaṁ yattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ na vaseyya, vasanto ca nārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalaṁ.
root_text.mn76:27.1: Puna caparaṁ, sandaka, idhekacco satthā takkī hoti vīmaṁsī.
root_text.mn76:27.2: So takkapariyāhataṁ vīmaṁsānucaritaṁ sayampaṭibhānaṁ dhammaṁ deseti.
root_text.mn76:27.3: Takkissa kho pana, sandaka, satthuno vīmaṁsissa sutakkitampi hoti duttakkitampi hoti tathāpi hoti aññathāpi hoti.
root_text.mn76:28.1: Tatra, sandaka, viññū puriso iti paṭisañcikkhati:
root_text.mn76:28.3: So takkapariyāhataṁ vīmaṁsānucaritaṁ sayampaṭibhānaṁ dhammaṁ deseti.
root_text.mn76:28.4: Takkissa kho pana satthuno vīmaṁsissa sutakkitampi hoti duttakkitampi hoti tathāpi hoti aññathāpi hoti’.
root_text.mn76:28.6: iti viditvā tasmā brahmacariyā nibbijja pakkamati.
root_text.mn76:29.1: Idaṁ kho, sandaka, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena tatiyaṁ anassāsikaṁ brahmacariyaṁ akkhātaṁ yattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ na vaseyya, vasanto ca nārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalaṁ.
root_text.mn76:30.1: Puna caparaṁ, sandaka, idhekacco satthā mando hoti momūho.
root_text.mn76:30.2: So mandattā momūhattā tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭho samāno vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjati amarāvikkhepaṁ:
root_text.mn76:30.3: ‘evantipi me no, tathātipi me no, aññathātipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me no’ti.
root_text.mn76:31.1: Tatra, sandaka, viññū puriso iti paṭisañcikkhati:
root_text.mn76:31.3: So mandattā momūhattā tattha tattha pañhaṁ puṭṭho samāno vācāvikkhepaṁ āpajjati amarāvikkhepaṁ—
root_text.mn76:31.4: evantipi me no, tathātipi me no, aññathātipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me no’ti.
root_text.mn76:31.6: iti viditvā tasmā brahmacariyā nibbijja pakkamati.
root_text.mn76:32.1: Idaṁ kho, sandaka, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena catutthaṁ anassāsikaṁ brahmacariyaṁ akkhātaṁ yattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ na vaseyya, vasanto ca nārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalaṁ.
root_text.mn76:33.1: Imāni kho tāni, sandaka, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāri anassāsikāni brahmacariyāni akkhātāni yattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ na vaseyya, vasanto ca nārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalan”ti.
root_text.mn76:34.2: Yāvañcidaṁ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāri anassāsikāneva brahmacariyāni anassāsikāni brahmacariyānīti akkhātāni yattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ na vaseyya, vasanto ca nārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalaṁ.
root_text.mn76:34.3: So pana, bho ānanda, satthā kiṁ vādī kiṁ akkhāyī yattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ vaseyya, vasanto ca ārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalan”ti.
root_text.mn76:35-42.1: “Idha, sandaka, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā …pe…
root_text.mn76:35-42.2: so ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
root_text.mn76:35-42.3: vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn76:35-42.4: Yasmiṁ kho, sandaka, satthari sāvako evarūpaṁ uḷāravisesaṁ adhigacchati tattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ vaseyya, vasanto ca ārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalaṁ.
root_text.mn76:43.1: Puna caparaṁ, sandaka, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā …pe… dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn76:43.2: Yasmiṁ kho, sandaka, satthari sāvako evarūpaṁ uḷāravisesaṁ adhigacchati tattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ vaseyya, vasanto ca ārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalaṁ.
root_text.mn76:44-45.1: Puna caparaṁ, sandaka, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati …pe… tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn76:44-45.2: Yasmiṁ kho, sandaka, satthari sāvako evarūpaṁ uḷāravisesaṁ adhigacchati tattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ vaseyya, vasanto ca ārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalaṁ.
root_text.mn76:46.1: Puna caparaṁ, sandaka, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā …pe… catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn76:46.2: Yasmiṁ kho, sandaka, satthari sāvako evarūpaṁ uḷāravisesaṁ adhigacchati tattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ vaseyya, vasanto ca ārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalaṁ.
root_text.mn76:47.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn76:47.2: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
root_text.mn76:47.3: Yasmiṁ kho, sandaka, satthari sāvako evarūpaṁ uḷāravisesaṁ adhigacchati tattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ vaseyya, vasanto ca ārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalaṁ.
root_text.mn76:48.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn76:48.2: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
root_text.mn76:48.3: Yasmiṁ kho, sandaka, satthari sāvako evarūpaṁ uḷāravisesaṁ adhigacchati tattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ vaseyya, vasanto ca ārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalaṁ.
root_text.mn76:49.1: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
root_text.mn76:49.2: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti;
root_text.mn76:49.3: ‘ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
root_text.mn76:50.1: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati.
root_text.mn76:50.3: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
root_text.mn76:50.4: Yasmiṁ kho, sandaka, satthari sāvako evarūpaṁ uḷāravisesaṁ adhigacchati tattha viññū puriso sasakkaṁ brahmacariyaṁ vaseyya, vasanto ca ārādheyya ñāyaṁ dhammaṁ kusalan”ti.
root_text.mn76:51.1: “Yo pana so, bho ānanda, bhikkhu arahaṁ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṁyojano sammadaññā vimutto paribhuñjeyya so kāme”ti?
root_text.mn76:51.2: “Yo so, sandaka, bhikkhu arahaṁ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṁyojano sammadaññāvimutto, abhabbo so pañcaṭṭhānāni ajjhācarituṁ.
root_text.mn76:51.3: Abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sañcicca pāṇaṁ jīvitā voropetuṁ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu adinnaṁ theyyasaṅkhātaṁ ādātuṁ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu methunaṁ dhammaṁ paṭisevetuṁ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sampajānamusā bhāsituṁ, abhabbo khīṇāsavo bhikkhu sannidhikārakaṁ kāme paribhuñjituṁ, seyyathāpi pubbe agāriyabhūto.
root_text.mn76:51.4: Yo so, sandaka, bhikkhu arahaṁ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṁyojano sammadaññāvimutto, abhabbo so imāni pañcaṭṭhānāni ajjhācaritun”ti.
root_text.mn76:52.1: “Yo pana so, bho ānanda, bhikkhu arahaṁ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṁyojano sammadaññāvimutto tassa carato ceva tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṁ samitaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ:
root_text.mn76:52.4: upamāyapidhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
root_text.mn76:52.6: tassa carato ceva tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṁ samitaṁ jānāti:
root_text.mn76:52.9: “Na kho, bho ānanda, so puriso satataṁ samitaṁ jānāti:
root_text.mn76:52.11: Api ca kho pana naṁ paccavekkhamāno jānāti:
root_text.mn76:52.13: “Evameva kho, sandaka, yo so bhikkhu arahaṁ khīṇāsavo vusitavā katakaraṇīyo ohitabhāro anuppattasadattho parikkhīṇabhavasaṁyojano sammadaññāvimutto tassa carato ceva tiṭṭhato ca suttassa ca jāgarassa ca satataṁ samitaṁ ñāṇadassanaṁ na paccupaṭṭhitaṁ:
root_text.mn76:52.15: api ca kho pana naṁ paccavekkhamāno jānāti:
root_text.mn76:53.1: “Kīvabahukā pana, bho ānanda, imasmiṁ dhammavinaye niyyātāro”ti?
root_text.mn76:53.2: “Na kho, sandaka, ekaṁyeva sataṁ na dve satāni na tīṇi satāni na cattāri satāni na pañca satāni, atha kho bhiyyova ye imasmiṁ dhammavinaye niyyātāro”ti.
root_text.mn76:53.4: Na ca nāma sadhammokkaṁsanā bhavissati, na paradhammavambhanā, āyatane ca dhammadesanā tāva bahukā ca niyyātāro paññāyissanti.
root_text.mn76:53.5: Ime panājīvakā puttamatāya puttā attānañceva ukkaṁsenti, pare ca vambhenti tayo ceva niyyātāro paññapenti, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.mn76:53.6: nandaṁ vacchaṁ, kisaṁ saṅkiccaṁ, makkhaliṁ gosālan”ti.
root_text.mn76:54.1: Atha kho sandako paribbājako sakaṁ parisaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.mn76:54.3: Na dāni sukaraṁ amhehi lābhasakkārasiloke pariccajitun”ti.
root_text.mn76:54.4: Iti hidaṁ sandako paribbājako sakaṁ parisaṁ uyyojesi bhagavati brahmacariyeti.

translation_text.mn76:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
translation_text.mn76:2.1: Now at that time the wanderer Sandaka was residing at the cave of the wavy leaf fig tree together with a large assembly of around five hundred wanderers.
translation_text.mn76:3.1: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Ānanda came out of retreat and addressed the mendicants:
translation_text.mn76:3.2: “Come, reverends, let’s go to the Devakata Pool to see the cave.”
translation_text.mn76:3.4: Then Ānanda together with several mendicants went to the Devakata Pool.
translation_text.mn76:4.1: Now at that time, Sandaka and the large assembly of wanderers were sitting together making an uproar, a colossal racket. They engaged in all kinds of low talk, such as
translation_text.mn76:4.2: talk about kings, bandits, and chief ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
translation_text.mn76:4.3: Sandaka saw Ānanda coming off in the distance,
translation_text.mn76:4.5: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound.
translation_text.mn76:4.6: The ascetic Ānanda, a disciple of the ascetic Gotama, is coming.
translation_text.mn76:4.7: He is included among the disciples of the ascetic Gotama, who is residing near Kosambī.
translation_text.mn76:4.8: Such venerables like the quiet, are educated to be quiet, and praise the quiet.
translation_text.mn76:4.9: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”
translation_text.mn76:5.1: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the wanderer Sandaka,
translation_text.mn76:5.4: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.
translation_text.mn76:5.5: Please sit down, this seat is ready.”
translation_text.mn76:5.6: Ānanda sat down on the seat spread out,
translation_text.mn76:5.7: while Sandaka took a low seat and sat to one side.
translation_text.mn76:5.9: “Sandaka, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
translation_text.mn76:5.10: “Worthy Ānanda, leave aside what we were sitting talking about just now.
translation_text.mn76:5.11: It won’t be hard for you to hear about that later.
translation_text.mn76:5.12: It’d be great if the worthy Ānanda himself would give a Dhamma talk explaining his own tradition.”
translation_text.mn76:5.13: “Well then, Sandaka, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn76:6.1: “Sandaka, these things have been explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha: four ways that negate the spiritual life, and four kinds of unreliable spiritual life. A sensible person would, to the best of their ability, not practice such spiritual paths, and if they did practice them, they wouldn’t succeed in the system of the skillful teaching.”
translation_text.mn76:6.2: “But worthy Ānanda, what are the four ways that negate the spiritual life, and the four kinds of unreliable spiritual life?”
translation_text.mn76:7.1: “Sandaka, take a certain teacher who has this doctrine and view:
translation_text.mn76:7.2: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.
translation_text.mn76:7.3: This person is made up of the four principal states. When they die, the earth in their body progresses and proceeds to the substance of earth. The water in their body progresses and proceeds to the substance of water. The fire in their body progresses and proceeds to the substance of fire. The air in their body progresses and proceeds to the substance of air. The faculties are transferred to space.
translation_text.mn76:7.4: Four men with a bier carry away the corpse.
translation_text.mn76:7.5: Their footprints show the way to the cremation ground.
translation_text.mn76:7.7: Offerings dedicated to the gods end in ashes.
translation_text.mn76:7.8: Giving is a doctrine of morons.
translation_text.mn76:7.9: When anyone affirms a positive teaching it’s just hollow, false nonsense.
translation_text.mn76:7.10: Both the foolish and the astute are annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and they don’t exist after death.’
translation_text.mn76:8.1: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:
translation_text.mn76:8.2: ‘This teacher has such a doctrine and view.
translation_text.mn76:8.11: If what that teacher says is true, both I who have not accomplished this and one who has accomplished it
translation_text.mn76:8.12: have attained exactly the same level. Yet I’m not one who says that both of us are annihilated and destroyed when our body breaks up, and we don’t exist after death.
translation_text.mn76:8.13: But it’s superfluous for this teacher to go nude, bald, persisting in squatting, tearing out their hair and beard. For I’m living at home with my children, using sandalwood imported from Kāsi, wearing garlands, fragrance, and makeup, and accepting gold and currency. Yet I’ll have exactly the same destiny in the next life as this teacher.
translation_text.mn76:8.14: What do I know or see that I should lead the spiritual life under this teacher?
translation_text.mn76:9.1: This is the first way that negates the spiritual life.
translation_text.mn76:10.1: Furthermore, take a certain teacher who has this doctrine and view:
translation_text.mn76:10.2: ‘The one who acts does nothing wrong when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. Nothing bad is done when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie.
translation_text.mn76:10.3: If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.
translation_text.mn76:10.4: If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, mutilating, and torturing, and encouraging others to do the same, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.
translation_text.mn76:10.5: If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, no merit comes of that, and no outcome of merit.
translation_text.mn76:10.6: In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is no merit or outcome of merit.’
translation_text.mn76:11.1: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:
translation_text.mn76:11.2: ‘This teacher has such a doctrine and view.
translation_text.mn76:11.7: If what that teacher says is true, both I who have not accomplished this and one who has accomplished it
translation_text.mn76:11.8: have attained exactly the same level. Yet I’m not one who says that when both of us act, nothing wrong is done.
translation_text.mn76:11.9: But it’s superfluous for this teacher to go nude, bald, persisting in squatting, tearing out their hair and beard. For I’m living at home with my children, using sandalwood imported from Kāsi, wearing garlands, fragrance, and makeup, and accepting gold and currency. Yet I’ll have exactly the same destiny in the next life as this teacher.
translation_text.mn76:11.10: What do I know or see that I should lead the spiritual life under this teacher?
translation_text.mn76:12.1: This is the second way that negates the spiritual life.
translation_text.mn76:13.1: Furthermore, take a certain teacher who has this doctrine and view:
translation_text.mn76:13.2: ‘There is no cause or reason for the corruption of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn76:13.3: Sentient beings are corrupted without cause or reason.
translation_text.mn76:13.4: There’s no cause or reason for the purification of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn76:13.5: Sentient beings are purified without cause or reason.
translation_text.mn76:13.6: There is no power, no energy, no human strength or vigor.
translation_text.mn76:13.7: All sentient beings, all living creatures, all beings, all souls lack control, power, and energy. Molded by destiny, circumstance, and nature, they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of rebirth.’
translation_text.mn76:14.1: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:
translation_text.mn76:14.2: ‘This teacher has such a doctrine and view.
translation_text.mn76:14.6: If what that teacher says is true, both I who have not accomplished this and one who has accomplished it
translation_text.mn76:14.7: have attained exactly the same level. Yet I’m not one who says that both of us are purified without cause or reason.
translation_text.mn76:14.8: But it’s superfluous for this teacher to go nude, bald, persisting in squatting, tearing out their hair and beard. For I’m living at home with my children, using sandalwood imported from Kāsi, wearing garlands, fragrance, and makeup, and accepting gold and currency. Yet I’ll have exactly the same destiny in the next life as this teacher.
translation_text.mn76:14.9: What do I know or see that I should lead the spiritual life under this teacher?
translation_text.mn76:15.1: This is the third way that negates the spiritual life.
translation_text.mn76:16.1: Furthermore, take a certain teacher who has this doctrine and view:
translation_text.mn76:16.2: ‘There are these seven substances that are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
translation_text.mn76:16.3: They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or both pleasure and pain to each other.
translation_text.mn76:16.5: The substances of earth, water, fire, air; pleasure, pain, and the soul is the seventh.
translation_text.mn76:16.6: These seven substances are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
translation_text.mn76:16.7: They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or both pleasure and pain to each other.
translation_text.mn76:16.8: And here there is no-one who kills or who makes others kill; no-one who learns or who educates others; no-one who understands or who helps others understand.
translation_text.mn76:16.9: If you chop off someone’s head with a sharp sword, you don’t take anyone’s life.
translation_text.mn76:16.10: The sword simply passes through the gap between the seven substances.
translation_text.mn76:16.11: There are 1.4 million main wombs, and 6,000, and 600; 500 deeds, and five, and three; deeds and half-deeds; 62 paths of practice, 62 sub-eons, six classes of rebirth, and eight stages in a person’s life; 4,900 Ājīvaka ascetics, 4,900 wanderers, and 4,900 dragon abodes; 2,000 lordships, 3,000 hells, and 36 realms of dusky sky; seven percipient embryos, seven non-percipient embryos, seven knotless embryos, seven gods, seven mental heavens, seven goblins, seven streams, seven castoff incarnations and 700 castoff incarnations, seven downfalls and 700 downfalls, seven dreams and 700 dreams, and 8.4 million great eons—through all of which the foolish and the astute transmigrate before making an end of suffering.
translation_text.mn76:16.12: And here there is no such thing as this: “By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life I shall force unripened deeds to bear their fruit, or eliminate old deeds by experiencing their results little by little”—for that cannot be.
translation_text.mn76:16.13: Pleasure and pain are allotted. Transmigration lasts only for a limited period, so there’s no increase or decrease, no getting better or worse.
translation_text.mn76:16.14: It’s like how, when you toss a ball of string, it rolls away unraveling.
translation_text.mn76:16.15: In the same way, after transmigrating the foolish and the astute will make an end of suffering.’
translation_text.mn76:17.1: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:
translation_text.mn76:17.2: ‘This teacher has such a doctrine and view.
translation_text.mn76:17.18: If what that teacher says is true, both I who have not accomplished this and one who has accomplished it
translation_text.mn76:17.19: have attained exactly the same level. Yet I’m not one who says that after transmigrating both of us will make an end of suffering.
translation_text.mn76:17.20: But it’s superfluous for this teacher to go nude, bald, persisting in squatting, tearing out their hair and beard. For I’m living at home with my children, using sandalwood imported from Kāsi, wearing garlands, fragrance, and makeup, and accepting gold and currency. Yet I’ll have exactly the same destiny in the next life as this teacher.
translation_text.mn76:17.21: What do I know or see that I should lead the spiritual life under this teacher?
translation_text.mn76:18.1: This is the fourth way that negates the spiritual life.
translation_text.mn76:19.1: These are the four ways that negate the spiritual life that have been explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha. A sensible person would, to the best of their ability, not practice such spiritual paths, and if they did practice them, they wouldn’t succeed in the system of the skillful teaching.”
translation_text.mn76:20.2: how these four ways that negate the spiritual life have been explained by the Buddha.
translation_text.mn76:20.3: But worthy Ānanda, what are the four kinds of unreliable spiritual life?”
translation_text.mn76:21.1: “Sandaka, take a certain teacher who claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus:
translation_text.mn76:21.2: ‘Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.’
translation_text.mn76:21.3: They enter an empty house; they get no almsfood; a dog bites them; they encounter a wild elephant, a wild horse, and a wild cow; they ask the name and clan of a woman or man; they ask the name and path to a village or town.
translation_text.mn76:21.4: When asked, ‘Why is this?’ they answer: ‘I had to enter an empty house, that’s why I entered it. I had to get no almsfood, that’s why I got none. I had to get bitten by a dog, that’s why I was bitten. I had to encounter a wild elephant, a wild horse, and a wild cow, that’s why I encountered them. I had to ask the name and clan of a woman or man, that’s why I asked. I had to ask the name and path to a village or town, that’s why I asked.’
translation_text.mn76:22.1: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:
translation_text.mn76:22.2: ‘This teacher makes such a claim, but they answer in such a way.
translation_text.mn76:23.1: This is the first kind of unreliable spiritual life.
translation_text.mn76:24.1: Furthermore, take another teacher who is an oral transmitter, who takes oral transmission to be the truth.
translation_text.mn76:24.2: They teach by oral transmission, by the lineage of testament, by canonical authority.
translation_text.mn76:24.3: But when a teacher takes oral transmission to be the truth, some of that is well learned, some poorly learned, some true, and some otherwise.
translation_text.mn76:25.1: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:
translation_text.mn76:25.2: ‘This teacher takes oral transmission to be the truth. He teaches by oral transmission, by the lineage of testament, by canonical authority.
translation_text.mn76:25.3: But when a teacher takes oral transmission to be the truth, some of that is well learned, some poorly learned, some true, and some otherwise.
translation_text.mn76:26.1: This is the second kind of unreliable spiritual life.
translation_text.mn76:27.1: Furthermore, take another teacher who relies on logic and inquiry.
translation_text.mn76:27.2: They teach what they have worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing their own perspective.
translation_text.mn76:27.3: But when a teacher relies on logic and inquiry, some of that is well reasoned, some poorly reasoned, some true, and some otherwise.
translation_text.mn76:28.1: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:
translation_text.mn76:28.2: ‘This teacher relies on logic and inquiry.
translation_text.mn76:28.3: They teach what they have worked out by logic, following a line of inquiry, expressing their own perspective.
translation_text.mn76:28.4: But when a teacher relies on logic and inquiry, some of that is well reasoned, some poorly reasoned, some true, and some otherwise.
translation_text.mn76:29.1: This is the third kind of unreliable spiritual life.
translation_text.mn76:30.1: Furthermore, take another teacher who is dull and stupid.
translation_text.mn76:30.2: Because of that, whenever they’re asked a question, they resort to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops:
translation_text.mn76:30.3: ‘I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.’
translation_text.mn76:31.1: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:
translation_text.mn76:31.3: Because of that, whenever they’re asked a question, they resort to verbal flip-flops and endless flip-flops:
translation_text.mn76:31.4: “I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.”
translation_text.mn76:32.1: This is the fourth kind of unreliable spiritual life.
translation_text.mn76:33.1: These are the four kinds of unreliable spiritual life that have been explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha. A sensible person would, to the best of their ability, not practice such spiritual paths, and if they did practice them, they wouldn’t complete the system of the skillful teaching.”
translation_text.mn76:34.2: how these four kinds of unreliable spiritual life have been explained by the Buddha.
translation_text.mn76:34.3: But, worthy Ānanda, what would a teacher say and explain so that a sensible person would, to the best of their ability, practice such a spiritual path, and once practicing it, they would complete the system of the skillful teaching?”
translation_text.mn76:35-42.1: “Sandaka, it’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed. …
translation_text.mn76:35-42.2: He gives up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
translation_text.mn76:35-42.3: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, he enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn76:35-42.4: A sensible person would, to the best of their ability, lead the spiritual life with a teacher under whom they achieve such a high distinction, and, once practicing it, they would complete the system of the skillful teaching.
translation_text.mn76:43.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant … enters and remains in the second absorption …
translation_text.mn76:46.2: A sensible person would, to the best of their ability, lead the spiritual life under a teacher who achieves such a high distinction, and, once practicing it, they would complete the system of the skillful teaching.
translation_text.mn76:47.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
translation_text.mn76:47.2: They recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. … They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.mn76:47.3: A sensible person would, to the best of their ability, lead the spiritual life with a teacher under whom they achieve such a high distinction, and, once practicing it, they would complete the system of the skillful teaching.
translation_text.mn76:48.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
translation_text.mn76:48.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. … They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.mn76:48.3: A sensible person would, to the best of their ability, lead the spiritual life with a teacher under whom they achieve such a high distinction, and, once practicing it, they would complete the system of the skillful teaching.
translation_text.mn76:49.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
translation_text.mn76:49.2: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
translation_text.mn76:49.3: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
translation_text.mn76:50.1: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
translation_text.mn76:50.2: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
translation_text.mn76:50.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.mn76:50.4: A sensible person would, to the best of their ability, lead the spiritual life with a teacher under whom they achieve such a high distinction, and, once practicing it, they would complete the system of the skillful teaching.”
translation_text.mn76:51.1: “But worthy Ānanda, when a mendicant is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—could they still enjoy sensual pleasures?”
translation_text.mn76:51.2: “Sandaka, a mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their heart’s goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—can’t transgress in five respects.
translation_text.mn76:51.3: A mendicant with defilements ended can’t deliberately take the life of a living creature, take something with the intention to steal, have sex, tell a deliberate lie, or store up goods for their own enjoyment like they used to as a layperson.
translation_text.mn76:51.4: A mendicant who is perfected can’t transgress in these five respects.”
translation_text.mn76:52.1: “But worthy Ānanda, when a mendicant is perfected, would the knowledge and vision that their defilements are ended be constantly and continually present to them, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking?”
translation_text.mn76:52.3: “Well then, Sandaka, I shall give you a simile.
translation_text.mn76:52.4: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.
translation_text.mn76:52.5: Suppose there was a person whose hands and feet had been amputated.
translation_text.mn76:52.6: Would they be aware that their hands and feet had been amputated constantly and continually, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking?
translation_text.mn76:52.7: Or would they be aware of it only when they checked it?”
translation_text.mn76:52.9: “They wouldn’t be aware of it constantly,
translation_text.mn76:52.13: “In the same way, when a mendicant is perfected, the knowledge and vision that their defilements are ended is not constantly and continually present to them, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.
translation_text.mn76:52.15: Rather, they are aware of it only when they checked it.”
translation_text.mn76:53.1: “But Reverend Ānanda, in this teaching and training, how many are emancipated?”
translation_text.mn76:53.2: “There are not just one hundred who are emancipated, Sandaka, or two or three or four or five hundred, but many more than that in this teaching and training.”
translation_text.mn76:53.4: Namely, that there’s no glorifying one’s own teaching and putting down the teaching of others. The Dhamma is taught in its own field, and so many emancipated are recognized.
translation_text.mn76:53.5: But these Ājīvakas, sons of she whose sons are dead, glorify themselves and put others down. And they only recognize three who have been emancipated:
translation_text.mn76:53.6: Nanda Vaccha, Kisa Saṅkicca, and the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla.”
translation_text.mn76:54.1: Then the wanderer Sandaka addressed his own assembly,
translation_text.mn76:54.2: “Go, good fellows. The spiritual life is lived under the ascetic Gotama.
translation_text.mn76:54.3: It’s not easy for me to forsake possessions, honor, or popularity now.”
translation_text.mn76:54.4: And that’s how the wanderer Sandaka sent his own assembly to lead the spiritual life under the Buddha.
